div.p: Bleak House is a mid 19th century novel by Charles Dickens, originally published in serialized form. The story of Bleak House follows the course of a legal dispute in the British Court of Chancery, as the Jarndyce family waits over generations to receive an inheritance they believe they deserve. The story is a commentary on the convoluted legal system in Britain, and the corruption inherent in it.
Through this edition, we are interested in examining the intertextuality between advertisements and different groups of readers, as well as the juxtaposition of ads and the prose text of the novel.

We choose not to modernize the text, since we wish to preserve the textual impact of the original 1852 publication. Thankfully, the language is not too far removed from what modern readers are comfortable with. Instead, to supply more context, we choose to annotate unfamiliar terms and concepts pertaining to 19th century British legal culture and Bleak House as a larger text.

div.note: The novel features the fictional case, Jarndyce and Jarndyce.
Royal seal of the United Kingdom.
